column4: Hey people. I have a question. Why is it that if I ssh (with X11 forwarding) to a remote host and run firefox THERE, it runs locally?
you have to do ssh -X yourhost yourcommandline if you want it to be run on your computer
of course this depends on what you mean by locally ...
I have firefox locally and also remotely. Now I KNOW that the local version is 3.0. The remote version is 2.0. When I run it WHILE logged on remotely, the local 3.0 version runs!
when I run firefox using ssh I get the remote version of firefox
it doesn't start my local version of firefox
yes... perhaps it's some kind of setting somewhere..
keep in mind that if I run xclock, it runs the remote version
but.. where is this defined.. I certainly haven't configured this.. have you?
nope... that's why I am asking here.
perhaps firefox does some kind of weird thing on startup.. I can't run one 32 bit firefox and one 64 bit firefox at the same time for example.. perhaps firefox is just the weird exeption here
ahh.. so it was firefox being weird.. good catch
I wonder who thought of this and figured.. yea.. let's do it like this..
but wait.. I'm the same user on both machines.. I should get that too..
ahh.. that might have been it
stupid people will do stupid things anyway.. this won't stop them =)
